results.title: Defense de Savoir = Forbidden to Know
results.brief_description:
Maitre Laube is a humble lawyer who is called on to the defense of Simone, a prostitute accused of murdering her lover. The lover was actually killed during a holdup, and was a member of a gang which did bullying favors for local politicians. Faced with Simone’s refusal to cooperate, Laube is left alone to unravel a much more complicated plot than he anticipated.

Credits: Producer, Raymond Danon ; director, Nadine Marquand Trintignant ; writers, Alain Corneau, Nadine Trintignant ; photography, William Lubtchansky ; music, Bruno Nicolai.
Cast: Jean-Louis Trintignant, Michel Bouquet, Bernadette Lafont, Juliet Berto, Claude Pieplu, Charles Denner, Barbara Laage, Serge Marquand, Marie Trintignant.

results.title: A Short film about love = Krotki filmo milosci
results.creator_credit: Krzysztof Kieslowski, Polish Corporation for Film Production and Tor-Film
results.brief_description: Tom, a lonely young man who lives in a cramped apartment with his mother, spies on the beautiful Magda - an older woman who lives in a high-rise apartment in the next block. Tom’s fascination with Magda turns into a loving obsession and he is determined to meet and be consumed by the object of his obsession. Based on an episode of his acclaimed television series, “Decalogue”, Kieslowski has crafted a beautifully melancholy movie about the fragility and pathos of love: though of different ages, classes and circumstances, both Tom and Magda share the desire to escape the banality of their lives through the transcendence of human communion.

results.title: A Bout de Souffle = Breathless
results.creator_credit: Georges de Beauregard and Jean-Luc Godard
results.brief_description:
Michel, on the run after shooting a policeman, is betrayed by his girlfriend, Patricia, an expatriate American. The plot is drawn from the ‘B’ crime thriller (the film is dedicated to Monogram Pictures, Hollywood’s all-B movie studio) and Godard pays homage to Hollywood’s action genres but his free approach to narrative and stylistics made this the most original and influential of the early New Wave films. The theme of the limits of personal freedom on the boundary between anarchism and nihilism emerges almost casually. The sense of dislocation is most obvious in Godard’s use of the jump cut, a device which he rarely, if ever, used again although he retained the effect. A more accurate translation of the title is ‘out of breath’ rather than the more romantic ‘breathless’.

Credits: Producer, Georges de Beauregard ; director, writer, Jean-Luc Godard ; photography, Raoul Coutard ; music, Martial Solal.
Cast: Jean-Paul Belmondo, Jean Seberg, Jean-Pierre Melville, Roger Hanin, Daniel Boulanger, Richard Balducci.

results.title: La Denonciation (Cinemascope Print)
results.brief_description:
Paris, 1961. Michel Jussieu, film producer, discovers the body of murdered political activist Georges Yvain on his way to a party. Haunted by guilt since he revealed under torture the names of members of his Resistance movement, Michel refuses to assist the police in the murder investigation and decides to conduct his own enquiry. Famous ‘Cahiers du Cinema’ critic Jacques Doniol-Valcroze films in a style very much influenced by the French New Wave the torments of a man coming to grips with his own guilt.

Credits: Producer, Pierre Braunberger, director, Jacques Doniol-Vacroze ; writer, Jacques Doniol-Valcroze ; photography, Henri Raichi ; music, Georges Delerue ; editor, Bob Wade ; assistant director, Jean-Louis Bunuel.
Cast: Maurice Ronet, Francoise Brion, Sacha Pitoeff, Michel Lonsdale, Jean-Claude Darnal, Nicole Berger, Raymond Gerome, Francois Maistre.

results.title: Edouard et Caroline = Edward and Caroline
results.creator_credit: Jacques Becker, Raymond Borderie and Robert Bossis
results.brief_description:
A young married couple quarrel on the eve of a party that can make or break the spouse’s career as a pianist.

Credits: Producer, Robert Bossis, Raymond Borderie ; director, Jacques Becker ; writers, Annette Wademant, Jacques Becker ; photography, Robert Le Febvre ; music, Jean-Jacques Grunenwald ; editor, Marguerite Renoir ; assistant director, Marcel Camus ;
Cast: Anne Vernon, Daniel Gelin, Jacques Francois, Elina Labourdette, Betty Stockfeld, Jean Riveyre.

results.title: Hardi! Pardaillan
results.brief_description:
Pardaillan has been entrusted by King Henri III with a letter he must pass on to Henri de Bearn. King Henri is besieged in the city of Chartres and is asking for help. After surviving many ambushes, Pardaillan must also contend with a fanatical monk who is plotting against the king. This is the second installment of the adventures of Pardaillan. See also: ‘Le Chavalier de Pardaillan’ (X000503) in our collection.

Credits: Producer, Henri Jaquillard ; director, Bernard Borderie ; writers, Henri-Andre Legrand, Andre Haguet, Bernard Borderie ; photography, Henri Persin ; music, Paul Misraki ; costumes, Rosine Delamare.
Cast: Gerard Barray, Valerie Lagrange, Philippe Lemaire, Guy Delorme, Jean Topart.

results.title: La Chartreuse de Parme = the Charterhouse of Parma
results.brief_description:
Fabrice returns to Parma to live with his aunt, Duchess Sanseverina. He is unaware of her feelings for him and looks for amourous adventures all over town. A jealous man challenges him to a duel and Fabrice kills him. After his arrest and trial, Fabrice is condemned to 12 years imprisonment and taken to the Farnese tower. There, he seduces Clelia, the daughter of the prison governor.

Credits: Producer, Andre Paulve ; director, Christian-Jaque ; writers, Christian-Jaque, Pierre Very, Pierre Jary ; photography, Nicolas Hayer, Romolo Garrone ; music, Renzo Rosselini.
Cast: Gerard Philipe, Renee Faure, Maria Casares, Lucien Coedel, Albert Remy, Louis Salou.

results.title: L'apprenti Salaud = the Apprentice Heel
results.brief_description:
Antoine was a pleasant and agreeable man for years, until a small inheritance begins to give him some dangerous ideas about gaining wealth and women. Partly in order to win the affections of a young woman, he becomes a small-time con man on the basis of some ideas his accountant has planted in his mind.

Credits: Producer, Philippe Dussart ; director, Michel Deville ; writer, Michel Deville ; photography, Claude Lecomte ; music, Georges Bizet.
Cast: Robert Lamoureux, Christine Dejoux, Claude Pieplu, Georges Wilson, Jean-Pierre Kalfon, Jacques Doniol-Valcroze, Jean-Francois Derec, Bernard Lavalette, Annick Blancheteau.

results.brief_description:

Cast: Charles Aznavour, Marie Laforet, Franco Fabrizzi.

results.title: Swan Lake
results.brief_description: A production of Peter Tchaikovsky’s much-loved ballet, featuring Rudolph Nureyev and Margot Fonteyn at the height of their partnership with the Royal Ballet in London. This fairy-tale, which began in Tchaikovsky’s imagination as a piece of fun for his nephews and nieces, is really the first thoroughly considered dance music drama, with a much more symphonic score than his other ballets. Over the years the ballet was savaged by cuts and substitutions, but with Nureyev’s choreography and Nicholas Georgiadis’s sets and costumes the underlying dramatic unity has been restored. The Wiener Symphoniker plays under the direction of John Lanchbury.
